document.name: myDocument

metadata.title: LA-PHYS-1.4 Projectile Motion
metadata.creator: Asseel
metadata.abstract: This document talks about what we've learned thus far in our physics modules with vectors and applies it in real world examples. By the end of this module, we will be able to mathematically describe projectile motion and obtain useful data from it.

document.script: function round(num, numDecimalPlaces) local mult = 10^(numDecimalPlaces or 0) return math.floor(num * mult + 0.5) / mult end

stack.p: Projectile Motion is the motion of an object that is moving as a result of earth's gravity. In the earlier modules, we learned that accelerations can be represented by vectors and we can break vectors a part to determine the net vector. All of what we've learned so far will be useful in this module. In the video above, see a game that uses projectile motion (in this case, the arrow). Using the same magnitude of force but different angles, the archer is able to nail the target.

sectionNoTitle.name: game

stack.p: To start this module off, try playing our projectile motion game down below. This is to help get an idea of how things work.
Use your finger or a stylus to angle the bow. Press Release to launch the arrow at the target before time runs out.

button.name: sim_button

drawing.name: plot

simulation.name: sim
timerSim
simulation.onUpdate: if countTime > -0.5 then countDown(countTime); else startButton:Click() end

button.name: startButton
button.onClick: if startButton.Text == "Start" then timerSim:Start(); startButton.Text = "Stop" else timerSim:Stop(); startButton.Text = "Start" gameScore = 0 gameAttempts = 0 end

sectionNoTitle.label: Release Angle (deg): 45

slider.name: release

stack.name: content
stack.p: As mentioned in the introdution, a projectile is an object that is being acted on by only gravity. Some examples of projectile motion include: a basketball shot, a rock dropped off a cliff, and a cannon firing. All of these examples are assumed to have no wind-resistance. If an object is moving without the force of gravity acting on it, it is not considered a projectile.

There are different types of projectile motions as well. Projectiles can be vertically launched, horizontally launched, both, or none. Solving projectile motion problems no matter what the initial condition is, it will always be helpful to break into x and y components.

stack.name: content
stack.p: The following is an example of how to solve a horizontal projectile motion problem.

stack.name: stack2
stack.p: A pool ball leaves a 0.60 meter high table with an initial horizontal velocity of 2.4 m/s. Predict the time required for the pool ball to fall to the ground and the horizontal distance between the table's edge and the ball's landing location.

stack.name: cont
stack.p: This step is used to visualize the problem and to label our given and missing variables.

simulation.name: sim1

button.name: btn1
btn

stack.name: stepStack
stack.p: Break into components and identify given variables.

button.name: btn

stack.name: stepStack
stack.p: Solve for time in the y-component

stack.name: cont
stack.p: We first use the y-component since we have enough data to solve for time. We can use the equation: $ y = v_{iy}t + \frac{1}{2}a_{y}t^2 $
This is the time required for the ball to fall to the ground.

button.name: btn

stack.name: stepStack
stack.p: Solve for horizontal distance in the x-component

stack.name: cont
stack.p: Now that we have the time, we can use it in the x-component to solve for horizontal distance.
We can use the same formula to solve this: $ x = v_{ix}t + \frac{1}{2}a_{x}t^2 $
Now we have found the horizontal distance.

button.name: btn

stack.name: content
stack.p: The following is an example of how to solve a non-horizontal projectile motion problem. A little more steps are required here since our inital conditions change for both the x and y components.

stack.name: stack2
stack.p: A football is kicked with an initial velocity of 25 m/s at an angle of 45-degrees with the horizontal. Determine the time of flight, the horizontal displacement, and the peak height of the football.

stack.name: cont
stack.p: This step is used to visualize the problem and to label our given and missing variables.

simulation.name: sim1

button.name: btn1
btn

stack.name: stepStack
stack.p: Break into components and identify given variables.

button.name: btn

stack.name: stepStack
stack.p: Solve for time in the y-component

stack.name: cont
stack.p: We first use the y-component since we have enough data to solve for time. We can use the equation: $ y = v_{iy}t + \frac{1}{2}a_{y}t^2 $
This is the time of the flight of the ball until it hits the ground.

button.name: btn

stack.name: stepStack
stack.p: Solve for horizontal distance in the x-component

stack.name: cont
stack.p: Now that we have the time, we can use it in the x-component to solve for horizontal distance.
We can use the same formula to solve this: $ x = v_{ix}t + \frac{1}{2}a_{x}t^2 $
Now we have found the horizontal distance the ball travels.

button.name: btn

stack.name: stepStack
stack.p: Solve the peak height of the ball.

stack.name: cont
stack.p: The peak height of a porabola occurs at half of the total fleight time. So to determine the max height, we have to use t = 1/2t.
We can use this formula to solve this: $ y = v_{iy}t + \frac{1}{2}a_{y}t^2 $
Now we have found the maximum height of the ball.

button.name: btn

stack.p: In the introduction, we showed a clip of a bowman shooting an arrow. Using the same steps as the previous examples, we are able to determine information from the bowmans shot. See the clip below.
Use the calculator below to solve projectile motion problems. Simply input the initial conditions and the calculator will output useful data such as the horizontal displacement and time.

stack.name: stack3

simulation.name: sim1

stack.name: btnStack1
stack.p: A cannon fires a ball with an initial velocity of 25m/s 53 above the horizontal. The cannon is sitting on top of a 60m cliff.
1. Determine the time it takes the ball to hit the ground

button.name: btn1
button.onClick: if tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "6" or tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "6.1" or tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "6.09" then btn1.Style.BackgroundColor = color.rgb(0, 255, 0); btn1.Text = "Correct!" else btn1.Text = "Try Again!" end

stack.p: 2. Determine the horizontal distance when the ball hits the ground.

button.name: btn1
button.onClick: if tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "91" or tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "91.6" or tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "92" then btn1.Style.BackgroundColor = color.rgb(0, 255, 0); btn1.Text = "Correct!" else btn1.Text = "Try Again!" end

stack.p: 3. Determine the maximum height that is reached by the ball.

button.name: btn1
button.onClick: if tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "75.36" or tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "75.4" or tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "75" then btn1.Style.BackgroundColor = color.rgb(0, 255, 0); btn1.Text = "Correct!" else btn1.Text = "Try Again!" end

stack.name: btnStack2
stack.p: A projectile is fired into the air from the edge of a 125m high cliff at an angle of 30.2 above the horizontal. The projectile hits a target 455m away from the base of the cliff.
1. Determine initial velocity of the projectile

button.name: btn1
button.onClick: if tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "59" then btn1.Style.BackgroundColor = color.rgb(0, 255, 0); btn1.Text = "Correct!" else btn1.Text = "Try Again!" end

stack.p: 2. Determine the time the projectile is in flight.

button.name: btn1
button.onClick: if tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "8.92" or tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "8.9" or tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "9" then btn1.Style.BackgroundColor = color.rgb(0, 255, 0); btn1.Text = "Correct!" else btn1.Text = "Try Again!" end

stack.p: 3. Determine the maximum height that is reached by the projectile.

button.name: btn1
button.onClick: if tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "159.8" or tb1.r1.c1.X.Text == "160" then btn1.Style.BackgroundColor = color.rgb(0, 255, 0); btn1.Text = "Correct!" else btn1.Text = "Try Again!" end
